content:
Sure, here’s an example of how the scoring process could look like based on a client’s answers to the intake form:
**Client Intake Form Answers:**
* Coaching Goals: I want to improve my leadership skills and advance my career in finance.
* Coaching Preferences: I prefer a collaborative coaching style and virtual coaching sessions. I am interested in learning about mindfulness practices.
* Coach Preferences: I prefer a female coach with at least 10 years of experience in the finance industry. I would like the coach to have a coaching certification of ICF PCC or above. I prefer the coach to speak English.
* Availability and Fees: I am available for coaching sessions on weekdays only. My budget for coaching fees is $200 per session.
**Scoring Process:**


| Criteria | Coach 1 | Coach 2 | Coach 3 | Coach 4 | Coach 5 |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Coaching Style | 3 | 5 | 4 | 4 | 5 |
| Specialization | 4 | 2 | 3 | 5 | 2 |
| Experience Level | 5 | 4 | 5 | 3 | 2 |
| Industry Experience | 5 | 3 | 4 | 2 | 3 |
| Coaching Certification | 5 | 4 | 3 | 4 | 2 |
| Language | 5 | 3 | 3 | 4 | 5 |
| Availability | 3 | 4 | 5 | 2 | 5 |
| Fees | 2 | 3 | 5 | 4 | 5 |
| Total Score | 32 | 28 | 32 | 28 | 27 |
Coach 1 has the highest total score with a score of 32, followed by Coach 3 with a score of 32. Since both coaches meet the client’s criteria, the director of coaching can review their availability and fees and select the coach who is the best match for the client’s needs.
By using this scoring process, the director of coaching can quickly and objectively evaluate each coach based on the client’s specific criteria and select the coach who is most likely to meet the client’s needs and preferences.
